title: Prohibition: 'real-time' remote biometric identification in publicly accessible spaces for law enforcement (with narrow exceptions)

article_refs.quote: Prohibit ‘real‑time’ remote biometric identification in publicly accessible spaces for law enforcement, except for narrowly defined objectives ...
... shall be deployed ... only to confirm the identity of the specifically targeted individual ...

legal_consequence.verbatim: Prohibited: placing/putting/using 'real-time' remote biometric identification systems in publicly accessible spaces for law enforcement, except for narrowly defined objectives and subject to strict safeguards and authorisations.

items.label: Recital (17) — RBI definition and 'real-time'
items.text: RBI identifies persons without active involvement; 'real-time' means capture, comparison, and identification without significant delay (no circumvention by minor delays).

items.label: Recital (19) — publicly accessible space
items.text: Any physical space accessible to an undetermined number of persons, irrespective of ownership/use (e.g., roads, transport hubs, parks, shops).

items.label: Recital (32) — intrusiveness and risks
items.text: Real-time RBI for LE is particularly intrusive, risks biased/discriminatory effects, and carries heightened risks due to immediacy and limited opportunity for correction.

items.label: Recital (33) — exhaustively listed exceptions
items.text: Use should be prohibited except in exhaustively listed, narrowly defined situations where strictly necessary to achieve substantial public interest that outweighs risks.

items.label: Recital (34) — identity only and strict limits
items.text: Deployment only to confirm the specifically targeted individual's identity and limited to what is strictly necessary in time, geography, and personal scope; authorities consider the nature of the situation and rights impacts.
